values: That, by the way, is a word that David Ives used in his play, "Ancient History." It describes the width and breadth of items I must address in this entry. 1) Online regulations have come from on high at work. Expect chances of me online during work hours to be slim or zip. I know, boo hoo, etc. I'll try to do more replying/posting at home. 2) Had a huge revelation! I should not be online at work, anyway. Excepting breaks or emergencies. I should just enjoy my job. What? I don't enjoy my job? Perhaps I should be applying for a different one. Your positive energy would be appreciated. Some apps and resumes are floating in the abyss, and I have hope. 3) Went to the doctor yesterday. For the first time since I moved to California over two years ago. Don't yell at me, , or anyone else for that matter. I lacked insurance! I was kind of nervous! I was lazy! I have a huge list of excuses! And besides, I just went! She and I had a good talk. Treating Poly-Cystic Ovarian Syndrome with BC and following up with an ultrasound (BLECH!), and weight management with behavioral dietician. This, I think, is a good thing. Also was referred to a sleep clinic for apnea. 4) When I first got my hearing aid in junior high, I remember walking outside and saying "so this is what the wind sounds like. And today, I can't stop thinking: "so this is what it feels like to be awake." Called the sleep clinic. They had a slot open last night, and signed me up! Those of you who've slept in the same room as I (I'm thinking , , among others) have heard both my obnoxious snoring and my scary-ass choking and have lived to make fun of me for it. Apnea kills brain cells and leaves sufferers exhausted. And I'm finally officially diagnosed! The sleep study itself was a little freaky. I had to arrive at the clinic at 10:00 pm, which was weird and spooky in itself. Then I had wires and microphones attached to every little curve of my face and neck and scalp to measure movement and air. My whole face was literally covered in tape. Then I had to fall asleep like that-- and flat on my back. I can't sleep flat on my back without choking every few moments or so, and it was a miserable few hours before the tech finally came in and put the Constant Positive Air Pressure (CPAP) machine on my nose. Which was a little freaky too, actually. Since the air pressure is constant, breathing out feels a little like swimming upstream. But eventually I dozed off, and didn't wake up for the rest of the night! When I was woken at 5:30, I felt like I'd had the best sleep of my entire life. Why didn't you all tell me I was the walking dead? I will have a consult with the doc in a 10 days or so, and then I will be prescribed a machine of my very own. Forget Darryl-- from now on, CPAP will be my snugglebunny. 5) My parents are officially retirees. They have purchased an RV! It's all tricked-out, too. Like a bachelor pad, it apparently has couches and chairs that flip or pop out at the touch of a button. Word is they'll be visiting CA for a whole month this winter! And dad has mentioned something about Winnebagoing out to a certain lit conference next year. Please feel free to mock the recreational vehicle owners. 6) Le boy returns from UK this weekend. I intend to pick Darryl up wearing my best romantic sundress (perhaps you know it... green checked, mid-fifties silhouette?) and take him to the Grove. 7) Azkaban! Azkaban Azkaban Azkaban Azkaban! Is one week from today. And I've done a brilliant job avoiding reviews and images and clips and spoilers. Unlike last time, I'd like to be surprised a bit this time. Nevertheless, from the sound of the articles and interviews I have seen, it looks to be the film I wanted it to be. 8) Witching Hour IP team-- have you read your transcript? Have you emailed me with the necessary questions and answers? Hmm?

Any of you have word on lovely <lj user="echo1976"> and the possible arrival of wee Owen-bean?  

Also, just wanted to announce that I feel happy today.  What a marvel.
to his alma mater, William and Mary. Katie has already posted it, but I'm re-posting for emphasis. Because if you haven't read it already, you should.

Angel ends tonight. Sigh. At least we're having a party to send it out properly. Which is, to say, with guacamole and alcohol. Wish you were here. Well, some of you will be. Listened to some of the testimony between various generals and government representatives regarding the Iraqi prisoner abuse. It was annoying. Take, as example, this exchange between an general and a senator (I didn't catch names. Who are you kidding? It was 6:15 am.) Senator: To your knowledge, were the rules of engagement ever reviewed by the secretary of defense? General: The secretary of defense is not required to review the rules of engagement. Senator: But to your knowledge, were the rules of engagement ever reviewed by him? General: To my knowledge, I never forwarded it to him. Senator: But to your knowledge, did he ever review them? General: What? Senator: To your knowledge, did the secretary of defense ever review the rules of engagement? General: The secretary of defense is not required to review the rules of engagement. Senator: But did he? General: I did not forward the rules of engagement to him. Senator: I-say-I-say, you are not answering my question! Other General who has Legal Experience: General, if I may, I was involved in the legal drafting of the document, and perhaps I can best answer for you. Senator: All right, then? General: The secretary of defense is not required to review the rules of engagement. Senator: *screams* Remind me never to get involved in politics. Edited to add: Curious. Looks like Life Skills or Health classes need to be required in Germany, too. You'd think that, at some point, they would have heard something about procreation. It sounds to me like a hoax.
Please leave an anonymous comment with three clues as to who you are, and I will venture a guess.

You can learn a lot of things from the flowers For especially in the month of June There's a wealth of happiness and romance All in the golden afternoon... I could only deny my genealogy and genetics for so long. From a line of farmers, it was inevitable that one day, I'd put my hands in the soil like those who came before me. At long last, another mostly-visual entry, this time depicting the sorts of flowers I planted in my new flowerboxes this weekend. These lovely cosmos are the centerpiece. A blush wine-colored celosia sprouts up below them. Buttery chrysanthemums pop up here and there. Trailing lobelia may have to be trimmed back in the long run! I always wished my mother would have planted dainty alyssum, but now I can plant my own. Creeping up five-foot wooden stakes, my jasmine vines smell incredible and will bloom three seasons out of four. Eventually, if I buy a proper trellis, they will frame my apartment door.

I read somewhere that John Williams wasn't fully involved in the score for Harry Potter-- that he had left it to his assistant? And that, for Prisoner of Azkaban, he decided to do it all himself. I don't know if it's true. But damn... DAMN, it sounds true. I'm online at the AOL Listening Party for the soundtrack, and it's amazing. It sounds so rich, and uses old themes and new ones to such chilling effect. Go listen! Now! Edited to say: Having given it a full listen-through, I have to say that the thing that stands out most to me is that Williams has upped the dramatic stakes with the music, which more than likely means that Cuaron and the production staff has upped the stakes as well. This is good news.

Last night I dreamed I was hostessing a party with Audra, and a slurry of people mingled and laughed and ate canapes.  In the midst of the blob ("Hi.  Dreadful.  Fabulous!") I was plagued with stomach pains and sunk, fetal, onto the couch.  And when I woke up?  I was plagued with stomach pains, sunk, fetal, on the couch.  Feeling bllaaaaaaugh today.

Remind me to stop googling old classmates.  It only makes me feel bad.  Also you might want to remind me that eventually it's possible someone might google my successes.  If I ever have any.

On the brighter side, it's been a long time since the primary word anyone has used to describe me was "graceful."  Not that I'm not.  I am graceful.  Just that it's rare that someone points it out now that I don't generally sport the slippers or tutu of the past.  So you can imagine my pleasure when le boy referred to me as a graceful lady.
Then you've got-to-got-to try a little tenderneeeeeess! And perhaps some in-vitro fertilization? Toy spoiler for Shrek 2.

1. Tower of Terror is just what California Adventure needs to put it on the right path to becoming a much better secondary park. It doesn't yet make it a full-day park, but it definitely improves it. While I miss the forward-motion 5th dimension room, there's a really awesome twilight-zone-mirror effect that makes this ride unique from its Florida cousin. 2. Hollywood Hills are difficult to navigate and harder to climb. The people with whom we mingled were lovely; other people in attendance were an eclectic bunch. I never realized that, in the presence of a man trying so hard to look cool and wealthy, I would want to punch him in the face a la Not!Canon!Hermione. 3. Dating can be lovely. I'd forgotten. 4. Once can accomplish so much when one is paired with someone who thinks in such a parallel way. And one meets with parallel-thinker for four hours. Draft of Witching Hour CFP is underway! And again, get out of my head, . IP team members on this list, keep an eye on your inbox this week. 5. Deadwood. Compelling. And I'm usually not that fond of western culture. Calamity Jane, what an actress! So curious about the brother-and-sister. Interesting to see a baser reflection of a society that was, by its own choice, base.

Sam's surgery went quite well-- better than his older sister's went four years ago (as she went under the knife for the same surgery; his cousin underwent a laser procedure for the same condition but it wasn't supported by Sam's doc.) He is in for a harder day today as his morphine wears off, but Michelle and family are troopers. We thank you for all of your directed energy and prayers-- it is much appreciated. The company my father, brother, friends' fathers, friends, (and previously, sister-in-law, mother, sister, and I) and the city of Midland MI at large works for is a Yahoo headline this morning. Dow Chemical announces layoffs. Interesting. And a little behind the times, I think? I've heard about it for months. I'm proud of my brother, who further climbed up the ladder in this shakedown. And now's probably a good time to announce that in related news... Dad's last day of work is tomorrow. He is officially retiring. And now, for hammocks and lazy summer days. And time with Mom. And trips to California, maybe?

Could you guys send some positive energy in the direction of my nephew Sam (2) and my sister's family?  He is in the middle of surgery for ureter reflux this morning.  He is the fourth child out of eight of my siblings' children to suffer it, and it's quite an invasive procedure.  

Also, please do the same for Robert Brentin, my beloved friend Stephanie's father, and all of his family.  A tree fell on him last Saturday, breaking his pelvis, his leg and his ankle, and tearing his bladder.  He is (last I heard) still in the ICU and will have to spend at least 6-8 weeks in the hospital.

Have you met Subservient Chicken? It's chicken. Your way. Literally. You can tell it to do anything. Things my friends have done include: "do the can-can." "do the macarena." "jump on the chair." "i love you, chicken." And, my favorite, "have sex with the couch." This is the weirdest niche marketing I've ever seen. Way to go, Burger King.

creepy: As if the eye-hooks from Clockwork Orange didn't scare me enough. blows-y: as if "Extreme Makeover" wasn't bad enough for playing on women's collective self-worth and body issues, now The Swan is toying with all that PLUS the tendency of society to encourage women to compete on the basis of appearance. sheepy: When I discovered this on the rhyming dictionary list for "rhymes with creep" I had visions of sheep chasing each other around in the swimming pool. beauxy: What's with the dates? Eh? Did the fates and the man upstairs decide, all of a sudden, that I need to be a social butterfly? Was set up--sort of-- by Disney pals, telling me to email a pal of theirs on our board. He soon thereafter suggested a lunch date. It was nice, chill, a casual late-lunch. He's sweet, and we have lots to talk about, but I'm not sure if either of us feel particularly strongly about each other. We might be bully chums, though. Double-blind has been postponed. My engineer forgot to ask his cousin if they'd be free-- and they're not, as cousin wraps filming that day. So engineer and I are setting up a one-on-one for an evening next week, and does not have to be pulled along by her toenails. Though she thinks she's getting out of it entirely. I think she's not. peep-y: but I'm not fond of them. Cadbury Creme Eggs for me, please. ring-around-the-rosie question

Ever have a hungry day? That's today. Would someone take these sugar wafers away from me? What? They're gone? Whoops. Absinthe is licoricious. As are 's college chums. Would somebody do away with savings/standard time? Screw the farmers, I just don't want to be late to work on the Monday following the changeover. "Dreamcatcher" is proof that Stephen King has really lost it. Post-vacation rest-up can span a weekend. Despite nifty salt-based shampoo, it turns out I do prefer Basin to Lush. Better bath bombs, and fortunately for me, closer store. Plus, almond-cherry soap for my ducky dish. I have a date next weekend. Kingsley Shackleboltish. Less Auror, more Oxford-educated Civil Engineer about to attend Stanford for PhD. I'm supposed to find a date for his handsome filmmaker cousin, but I'm having trouble finding single gals who wouldn't kill me for suggesting a blind date. I suspect if I invited I'd get a blunt object over the head. Whichever of you stated that Colin Firth spent the entirety of "What a Girl Wants" looking uncomfortable about being a cute teenager's father was spot-on. Happy bithday to ! Edited to add: Oh, look! Here I was, thinkin' I was a Potter fandom-nobody. Apparently I'm good enough to be added by a troll!

Back at work to rest up from lovely and exhausting vacation.

Promise to catch up on email by weekend.

During my favorite friends episode, "The One Where No One's Ready" (which was aired in primetime last night as a part of the "best of" finale countdown-- you might remember its classic references to "going commando") Chandler poses an intriguing question about Donald Duck's habit of wrapping a towel around his waist after a shower. Odd, of course, because Donald Duck does not generally wear pants. I grant you, before I leave, a link to the official Disney FAQ, which, believe it or not, answers this question. I will now make like a banana and split. Back on the tricky 4/1.

Today I saw "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind." It was quite better than its lovely screenplay in some ways, and outshined by it in others. If you've seen the film already and are interested in the path from page to screen, I suggest you read an early draft, now online here. If you do, keep an eye out for the lovely literary/poetic/musical references that Kaufman originally made-- all are lovely and conspicuously missing. Also check out the bookender scenes. While in its celluloid form, "Sunshine" finally offers a solid Kaufman third act, I felt that the original draft featured perfect ending. Nevertheless, it's a film well worthwhile the admission, and knowing how many of you have had similar lovelife experiences to mine, I suspect you'll be as equally moved. Solid performances, especially a moving one by Jim Carrey. Vivid and sometimes (properly) spastic directing. This one'll be long close to my heart. Then I saw "The Passion of the Christ." I could probably boil my reaction down to two words: "Jesus Christ." But as it's a very personal reaction, I'll get a little more specific behind the cut. I don't need to look at anyone's tacky two-bit depiction of an floaty maggot-nosed androgynous devil to recognize that there is evil in the world. I don't have to witness a special effects team's depiction of flesh being torn away from a dummy's ribs to understand what Christ's sacrifice means to me. I don't want to be told, in any circumstance other than God coming to tea, that anything is "exactly what happened." Tonight my father likened faith to buying a house without being able to go inside. You'd want to be able to look in as many windows as possible. I like that metaphor. There are some stories that need to be told by four different narrators to help us to barely begin to grasp the enormity of the message. To condense it down to one is to simplify what needn't be simplified. As a filmmaker, I think that Mel Gibson has an unhealthy obsession with slo-mo. And an unhealthy obsession with depicting characters he doesn't like as fey. And an unhealthy obsession with gore-- no more than Tarantino-- but to watch a film in which only the non-gory flashbacks are touching or appealing, one has to wonder why he didn't just make a whole movie of them.

I feel weird quoting a review on the release day of "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" that isn't from that movie, considering I read the screenplay last fall and I've been jonesing for it ever since.  So.  First, I'll say:  GO SEE "SPOTLESS MIND." 

Then, I'll say:
God bless NY Times' A. O. Scott.  From his review of "Taking Lives"--

"From a technical standpoint, Taking Lives is competent and sometimes even impressive. It is cleanly edited and nicely shot -- at times as cool and rich as a York Peppermint Pattie. Beyond that, there is not much to say. Those smashed-up corpses -- they sure are gruesome. That Angelina Jolie -- she sure has some pair of lips. That Kiefer Sutherland -- he sure can be creepy. That Ethan Hawke -- he sure is in this movie."

I lasted, like, a year and a half on this livejournal before I started revealing how embarrasingly much I like Disneyana. I give up trying to be nonchallant and businessy about it. [squee]I'm going to Disney World next week![/squee] (Why this is any different than my monthly trip to Disneyland is a mystery-- other than the presence of beloved family, and a keen African restaurant called Boma. And Mission: Space! And Philharmagic! And I have nieces and nephews with whom I can ride Dumbo so I don't have to look like a twenty-something who likes Dumbo! And I'm a huge geek!) Anyway, there was a column today on Mouse Planet that discussed why some people are gaga over Disney parks (and products) and some are so nonchallant. The writer implied that the biggest Disneyana fans grew up in the 50s and 60s, because they witnessed the opening of Disneyland and the rise of Disney on TV. This is my response: "I enjoyed your ponderings on the "zone" and its possible origins, but I have one item of contention: you suggest that a majority of people in the zone grew up in the 50s and 60s. You failed to consider that the children of the Disney Boomers would also grow up to zone out in Disney parks, during Disney movies and here on Disneyana-loving websites. "Many of my friends that grew up 80s had parents who attended or longed to attend Walt's first park in Anaheim. So when WDW opened, the boomers took my generation of zone-heads to the park. And we went back again, and again, and again. (Heck, my family is going back next week, but having blossomed from 5 to 15 members, we're creating a third generation in the zone!) "Those same boomers that witnessed the rise of Disney on television via the 'Disneyland' show in its many guises later pounced upon the premium Disney cable channel when it was first introduced. I still remember the day the cable man came to install it-- the whole family gathered together to watch it. "The zoners of the 80s were at a prime age when the canon of films were released on VHS-- we were able to see, at our leisure, all the films that so affected our parents, and in turn affected us. And that includes 'Darby O'Gill and the Little People.' "And finally, when the studio started putting out its best work in years, the children of the 1980s were the target audience for the film that issued in the second golden age-- 'The Little Mermaid.' "If you need evidence, look around the parks... twenty and thirtysomethings are everywhere. Even those of us without children. We collect, we visit, we pass on the love of the brand that defined our parents' age and our own. Don't forget about us!" So, friends. Disney parks. Yay, or nay? And if it's nay, why? And if it's yay, tell me what you like best.

and we'd like to see what the friendslist has to say about this, so if you have a moment, please answer the poll.  If you're reading this but you aren't on livejournal, please post your answer as a comment.  Thanks!

Thanks to all for the birthday wishes! It was a lovely day. Memes. Get your memes. Trailers for films I want to see..."> Hellboy Saved! Shrek 2 Duh. Anchorman Connie and Carla Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind Mean Girls is written by Tina Fey! Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow The Incredibles As of yet, no trailers for "The Life Aquatic" or "The Wendell Baker Story" or "The Aviator" or "De-lovely." Name meme... If you know me as Heidi, you're just about everyone. If you know me as Heidi Jo, we were in 6th or 7th grade together. And you made fun of me. Or you're Molly. If you know me as H-Jo, you were in "The Most Massive Woman Wins." If you know me as HJ, you're on livejournal or you're my father or my sister, or you went to high school with me, or work with me. If you know me as H, you're Audra, Rachel, Sarah, or Steph. If you know me as powersh20works you're on livejournal. If you know me as powerswaterworks you have my IM or email address. If you know me as LSPoorEeyorick you're a Disney fan. If you know me as GrrrlArgh you're from Cross & Stake If you know me as Morley1013 you're Brent, or had my email address in 1998. If you know me as HJSondheim you had my email address in 1995. If you know me as lady, you're a smattering of girlfriends I also call lady. If you know me as Ms. Powers you were my professor. If you know me as Moose or Burger you are a family member. If you know me as Buttersquash, you are Aimee. If you know me as Heidi Ho Heidi Jo you annoy me. 12 things in a box... So, say you were meeting a new person and you wanted them to have some idea of what kind of person you are, and who you are. But you can't actually tell them in so many words. Instead, you have to give them a box, with a dozen things in it for them to ponder over. What would you put in the box? No cheating -- you're not allowed to include things such as links to your LiveJournal. 1) Pictures from my scrapbook 2) Copy of "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban" 3) Copy of "Cockroaches in Love" 4) Blue and yellow scarf and blue oval necklace 5) Bust of Shakespeare 6) Disneyland Annual Pass 7) Collection of Menus-- Zingerman's, Sushi Zawa, Morel's, the little Thai place we go to, Greek's, Victoria and Albert's, the Blue Bayou, Mediterrano's, The Sweet Onion, The Gandy Dancer, Tony's Pizza 8) Pink overcoat with hat, scarf, and matching purse containing Cargo lip gloss, Dior powder, Chanel Chance perfume 9) Jean jacket with Doc Martins, over-the shoulder bag from Peru containing "peas on earth" wallet, Carmex, and moisturizer 10) Mix CD which would include "Au Fond du Temple Sainte" from Bizet's The Pearl Fishers, "Hallelujah" from Shrek, "Summer Highland Falls" by Billy Joel, "It's Your Move (Seen All Good People)" by Yes, "Yo Ho! A Pirate's Life for Me," "Do You Realize" by Flaming Lips, "Kate" by Ben Folds Five, "Pink Moon" by Nick Drake, "Teenage Wasteland" by Who, "In My Life" by Beatles, "Under Pressure" by Bowie, and "Wonderful World/Somewhere Over the Rainbow" as recorded by IZ. 11) Copy of "When Harry Met Sally" 12) writing materials and digital video camera

Happiest of happy birthdays to <lj user="shakespearechic">!

May you delight in the break of spring that arrives in the light of our own arrival.  May your happy moments be remembered today and may more be made.  May you get going on your fiction so I can be betagal again!

I figured I'd also do the meme-for-significant-day that's winding its way through my friendslist's <lj-cut text="significant days...">significant days...

1979 Made it through difficult pregnancy for mom, without being affected by her blood thinner.  Born in Midland, Michigan.  Moved within months to the house I lived in until I left for college.  Am read to immediately upon arrival home by brother.  Sister likes to waste laundry by playing "dress-up" with me.  

1980 First words are "mama" and "dada," if I'm correct.  Ride Bucky the Wonder Horse down the stairs.

1981 Start reading lessons with mom. 

1982 Hence the reading at age three. No kids around; pretending a lot.  Richard Simmons is chief imaginary friend.  Thus begins attraction to gay men.  Am generally happy child.

(83-)1984 Preschool.  Have first boyfriend, Steven Wayne.  Graffiti my toy box in permanent marker with the words "I love Steven Y".  Read well, don't spell really well apparently.  Family to Walt Disney World for sister's graduation.  Uncle dies.  Sister leaves for University of Michigan.

(84-)1985 Kindergarten at St. Brigid School.  Going through some life adjustment.  Bury cabbage patch kid in the basement.  Have panic attack when squirrel gets hit by car.  Go into therapy with priest friend-of-family.  Start dance classes.  Get better.  Ressurect dead cabbage patch kid.  Fall in love with Walter Buzanowski.  See Disney's "Robin Hood" for the first time.  Graffiti my closet door with "R. H. + M. M." in a heart.  Thus begins my attraction to Brits.  Another boy in my class skips kindergarten because he can read.  Promptly pretend I cannot read.  Parents are shocked at my bad reading report card.  They cook up a scheme with the teacher and am tricked into revealing I can in fact read when the teacher gets to the climax of the short story she's reading and is "interrupted," saying "I have to go check on something.  Heidi, will you take over reading?"  Stupidly, I do.  Thus begins my career of being a bad liar.

(85-)1986 First grade.  Begin piano lessons.  Am good friends with Mary Wazny.  Walk a mile to her house without supervision.  Freak out parents.  Inspired by my siblings' interest in theatre, I begin to stage full-scale teddy bear productions starring me.  Lots of "Annie."  In love with brother's friend Brian Borg who played Charlie Brown.  He writes me notes.  Wonder where he is today?

(86-)1987 Second grade.  Family to Walt Disney World for brother's high school graduation.  Write some cute books in class.  Brother leaves for University of Michigan.

(87-)1988 Third grade. Am only child left in house.  Cease being cute, get ugly for a couple of years.  Made first real "best" friend, Kim B.  She's a bad influence; like her very much.  Bully Chris Max puts a worm in my hair.  

(88-) 1989 Fourth grade.  Have fight with school over saxophone.  They want me to play clarinet first.  Parents win.  Can try out for first children's play!  Am not cast.  Am crushed.  Have first-year teacher.  She's terrible, giving tests that can't be read.  Walter's parents and mine fight the school.  Parents win.  Bully Chris Max pushes me down in the dust, ruining yellow pants.

(89-)1990 Fifth grade.  Kim moves away.  Am cast in "Winnie-the-Pooh," as Tulip Turtle.  No lines.  Steal show anyway in my five-minute slow-mo cross of stage.  Greasepaint stinky.  Tattle on Bully Chris Max's crayon porn.  Win second place at school spelling bee.  Lose regionally with "Airplain."  Spelling still tricky.

(90-)1991 Sixth grade.   Decide, stupidly, to go by "Heidi Jo."  Sister is married, am maid-of-honor.  Am mistaken for 16 by several, including groom's cousin.  First kiss by a boy, even though it's the best man and it's staged.  Had surprise birthday party.  Walter Buzanowski "goes steady" with Mary Wazny.  Does not dance with me because "Vanilla Ice says 'everybody fall in line with yo girl.'"  Am crushed.  Quit dance to pursue theatre.

(91-)1992 Seventh grade at Central Intermediate.  New lot of people. Meet best friend Katy on first day.  Meet Brentley.  Run unopposed for student council with slogan "You're in the know with Heidi Jo.  Powers for Historian!"  Have hand motions.  Never live this down.  Go back to "Heidi" immediately.  Have character role in school play "Undercover Romance."  Have character role in community theatre "Aladdin."  Have solo in Teenage Musicals production of "Pajama Game."  Interested in journalism.  First nephew born.  

(92-)1993 Eighth grade.  Cute again.  Have character role in school play "Illinois Pete."  Have character role in community theatre "Up 2 U," worst-written play ever.  Am Features Editor of newspaper, win awards.  Am pom-pon girl both seasons.  In fall, believe I am hated by other pommers.  Win squad-voted MVP award.  Am baffled to this day.  Brother is married, am bridesmade.  Take two-week tour of East coast and Canada with parents.  See "Phantom" and "Cats."  Meet Matt at church, think he's cute.

(93-)1994 Ninth grade. Co-editor of newspaper, win awards.   Second nephew is born.  Have lead role in "Robin Hood" at school, character role in "Tied to the Tracks."  Ditch Matt for Walter at church activity; am kind of mean.  Make a big decision to go to school I'm closest to so as to be able to letter in pom-pon sophomore year.  Am in ballet chorus of "Oklahoma!" for Teenage Musicals.  Meet Jeff, playing Ali Hakim.  Fall hopelessly in crush.  Jeff convinces me to forgo pom and try out for play.  

(94-)1995 Tenth grade at Dow High. Parents force me to try out for pom because that was planned.  Try out as terribly as I can.  Ballet chorus choreographer is pom coach.  Puts me on squad anyway.  Hate it!  Work backstage for play. Ast. Feature Editor with newspaper.  Member of German Klub without speaking language; long story.  Ask Jeff to homecoming too late.  He works that night.  Nancy Twinkle in "Little Mary Sunshine," also choreographer.  First taste of directing.  Jeff is Captain Billy.  Matt and Brent both soldiers in love with me.  We take Little Mary to State competition.  Am still friends with most of the people involved.  Am allowed first date on 16th birthday.  With Jeff.  To bad chain Mexican food between rehearsal for "Joseph" and band practice.  Jeff takes me to prom.  He graduates and goes to Michigan.  First job at McDonald's.  Hate it!  People-to-People international trip to Australia and New Zealand.  Brilliant.

(95-)1996 Eleventh grade. Goddaughter is born.  Am quite close to Ashley/Anirban, Stephanie/Todd, and Jessica/Beau, all younger/older couples.  Played role of Stage Manager in "Our Town," Fairy Godmother in "Cinderella."  Choreograph "Guys and Dolls."  Parents schlepp me back and forth from Michigan to see Jeff.  Opinions Editor for newspaper.  Write first humor column.  Reveal accidentally to Matt that everyone has been told about his closet.

(96-)1997 Twelfth grade.  Top of world.  Steady boyfriend.  Co-editor of newspaper with Stephanie.  Best Thespian award, Baker's Wife in "Into the Woods," Mrs. Johnstone in "Blood Brothers."  Directed "Fools,"  is a smashing success.  Jeff in play involving nudity and groping thereof at college.  Huge fight.  Take him to prom, take him to Walt Disney World with family for graduation.  Break up.  Leave for University of Michigan where we manage to avoid each other.  Except when I hear a rumor about his orientation.

(97-)1998 Freshman. New set of folks once again.  Close to Aimee, Lisa, Molly.  Rob is infamous flower-giving boy with something to say that ended up being "I'm gay."  Lady Macduff in "Macbeth," get promoted within Rude Mechanicals company to Associate Producer.  Begin directing track with School of Music.  Mom gets ITP, is a trooper.

(98-)1999 Sophomore. Second niece is born.  First apartment with Aimee.  Boy Justin comes on to Matt at a party.  Boy David comes out to me.  Issuing out the gay movement and on to the crazy one.  Date Pete but he's too crazy.  Promoted to Rude Mechanicals chair.  Produce "Tempest" and "All My Sons."  Direct original play.  Begin English track.  Intern with Phoenix Theatre in Indianapolis.  Crash with sister and family.  Date Crazy Overcompensating Matthew.

(99-) 2000 Junior.  Matt transfers, moves into apartment.  Direct "Much Ado About Nothing."  Meet Crazy Pat and begin to spend every spare moment with him.  Direct "Ancient History."  Still spending too much time with Crazy Pat.  He doesn't like me to spend time with anybody else.  Infamous "Germany a la Felicity" incident.  Intern with Shakespeare Theatre in Washington D.C.

(00-)2001 Senior.  Direct deconstructionist "Hamlet," Pat is finally is social with my friends.  All is well.  All turns ugly.  All spend next semester crying.  Twin niece and nephew are born.  Hang out with--oddly-- Walter Buzanowski in English classes.  Finally not in love with him.  Bump into Bully Chris Max, who apologizes for bullying and asks if I've become a mathematician or an actress because he always knew I would.  Feel validated!  Realize that "he teases you because he looooves you" is true.  Direct thesis, "Most Massive Woman Wins."  Critics and audiences cheer.  Take some writing classes and am encouraged by screenwriter to make writing a goal again.  Graduate with BFA and BA and leave for the metropolis of Midland.

2002 Ashley/Anirban are married, am bridesmaid.  Jessica/Beau are married, Steph is bridesmaid.  Jeff married.  Pat married.  Goddaughter asks if all my "old boyfriends are married."  Answer is mortifyingly yes, even Walter Buzanowski and Bully Chris Max.  Am considering a national search to find Steven Wayne.  Steph becomes Single-Soulmate.  Fear owning six cats at sixty.  Live with parents until April.  Move to Los Angeles.  Know no one.  Make it to the end of the Director's Guild training program competition but don't make the final cut.  Have bad temp jobs.  Scared of men.  Not my year, really.  Hang out at Cross & Stake, and that's nice, especially the Punky Bunch.  Discover the world-o-Potter.  That's nice, too.  Commence with livejournal.  Fourth nephew is born.

2003 Date a little casually.  Less crazy, one gay.  Make friends in the apartment building.  Help run a church group for young adults.  Meet Audra, who moves to the building shortly.  Have frequent teafest.  Get a temp job that functions and am offered benefits.  Promptly sell out.  Write at night!  Sign on to Witching Hour.  Still close to Michigan friends and family.  Godson is born.  Mom gets cancer, is a trooper.  

2004 Write.  Work.  Live.  Still enamored with brits and gays, and gay brits.  Still bad speller, still bad liar.  Graffiti less.    Turn 25 without a quarter-life crisis, hopefully.  Have... plans.
made mention of Teacupgate on the NPR show Wait Wait Don't Tell Me." Follow link to "Uncle Walt must be spinning in his cryogenic freeze." Our plight has reached VH-1 G-list celebrities!

of an entry, probably the last (save for one already-written Wednesday entry) for the week since it's a ridiculously busy one. 1) The Witching Hour website is up and running. Come and appreciate teh pretty. 2) The LA Times has been following teacupgate and graced the cause with a funny editorial. If you hadn't heard about this before, a the Time's initial article is here. I am only marginally embarrassed to have been at the first passholder-storming of City Hall mentioned near the end of the story. And hardly embarrassed at all to have met every one of the fans quoted. 3) Mom has finished her 33 radiation treatments. Hurrah! She's still in a huge amount of pain, but she seems to be turning a corner a little, so hopefully she'll have healed by the time she leaves for the family Orlando trip in two weeks.

Some general augh-ing about the Disney turn of events, and JK Rowling's online chat transcripts. But first, a question... If you can name the fan or experts who will be most likely interviewed for public news stories about something, I think that makes you an semi-ultimate geek. I can name likely interviewees (or, ultimate geeks) for five different fan-type communities (some in which I do not participate), and have seen them all interviewed nationally. I know some of them. What does this say about me? And, how many can you name? Eisner was booted a fews after yesterday's meeting from his position as Chairman of the Board. He remains on as CEO. What gall, what balls of that board to spin that 43% vote-of-no-confidence as limited to only the chairman position. And, what gall, what balls of the board to promote former senator George Mitchell to Chairman AFTER he, himself, had receied a 25% vote-of-no-confidence. Isn't it standard that anything above 20% is expected to step down from the position? Why, then, would they promote him? Are they just going ignore that vote? And aren't they going to toss Eisner out on his posterior after something that embarassing for the company? AUGH! Just because JK Rowling talks the big doublespeak about who will end up with whom, it does not mean that it supports your ship (or doesn't.) I'm far beyond pretending I don't like Harry with Hermione (I Mary Sue Me.) (Read that two ways; I Mary Sue "me". Sue me.) But I really don't believe that anything she said is definitive about Harry/Hermione, Ron/Hermione, Hermione/Krum, (yes, , Hermione/Draco) or Giant Squid/Dennis. Am disappointed to see that Sirius was not in Slytherin. When will we see a good Slytherin? Will it, please, be Dumbledore? Have back-stepped from my opinion that we'll never see Sirius again, because I think she back-stepped, too. Some people were asking questions that made me think of Comic Book Guy. "In episode G38-19, Radioactive Man has his ionic sword, but he had lost it in episode G39-13; how can this be?" Neville has had his turning point! Why did nobody ask about the replacement of his wand--which, we know, was his father's, not his own perfect match. "A certain Ms. Radcliffe is desperate" to have the Hermione/Draco question answered? Are we to assume she meant Emma Watson (in which case, does Watson believe H/D is a possibility, and is she Mary-Sue-ing, and thence is Felton the one she's "in love with, professionally"?) Or is it Daniel to whom she refers, in which case, is he as gay as we all guessed? Or did Emma and Dan get married in a secret and illegal ceremony? Nothing, nothing, nothing of Snape! Except that she again yammers that if she reveals anything, it'll give stuff away. Duh. Well, Aud, I guess no patronus or boggart answer for you. No limits to your imagination yet. Yes, that patronus is obviously a unicorn. Pure, virginal heart, that one. Two questions for readers with good memories or people with books nearby: 1) From OotP, what is Hermione's patronus? 2) From Fantastic Beasts, What is Crookshanks, if not all cat? I thought I wasn't ready to get excited about book 6, seeing as I am taking what is apparently going to be eight months to re-read 5 (to make up for reading it in two days initially.) Turns out, though, I am. And no ETA in sight. AUGH!

The stockholders have spoken.

In a race where Eisner ran against nobody, 43% of the stockholders voting by proxy voted to not re-elect him! 

News services everywhere are reporting that it's the largest vote-of-no-confidence for a CEO ever.  It's only a short while until they remove the tool from his position!

Glee.  Joy and glee.

It's a laugh-fest. It's awfully bizarre, and I'm listening to it live. It's the Disney shareholder meeting, and between Eisner's terrible spin and the audience's huffy questions and decision to ignore whatever agenda is set down, it's made for an interesting morning soundtrack. And we're all waiting with bated breath to see if Roy Disney's "savedisney.com" grassroots movement calling for shareholders to vote against Eisner worked. They're not announcing it until the end. *crosses appendages*
It came.... from her toothbrush. The strep has returned.

It was a hellish Saturday-day spent with Honey the Toyota Corolla. A very boring blow-by-blow is as such: 8:30-arrive at garage for oil change, wash, and smog check. 9:00-told that engine belt must be replaced, and smog check cannot be performed there. 10:00- arrive at suggested smog check. failed it due to missing gas cap. 10:30- purchase gas cap from parts store. return to nearby mechanic to turn engine light off. 11:00- drive around for an hour to insure engine light does not return. 12:00- arrive back at smog check. There is a huge line. 1:40- arrive at combo insurance/dmv office to transfer registration/license/insurance from MI to CA. 3:00- finally sign papers. It runs, all told, $750. It was a marvelous Saturday-night spent with Aud and Soph and gang. Not only did it make up for the dmv stress, I had completely forgotten the mess by approximately 7:30 that evening. Hurrah for good company and good beer and Eleanor of Aquitane. The two things I liked most about last night's television festivities: 1) My love for (and crush on) Andrew Stanton grew tenfold. Tenfold. He's written every Pixar movie, he's funny and charming... AND he gushed with love for his adorable chubby high school sweetheart wife in front of the whole world. I can't even hold a grudge against her. They're too cute to be jealous. 2) The opening moments of the half-hour preshow, in which Keisha Castle-Hughes wished most to meet Johnny Depp because she deemed him a "total stud," and the subsequent closing moments of said show, where she met Johnny Depp and he gushed all over her.

Unless you're , in which case, please pass me your dust; my spoon is ready. A gang of us had an Oscar pool. Of all awards, I only missed on four (two of which I suspected I'd miss on-- best actor and best live short.) I may not be the tops, but I'm personally proud. Picks are here. Let me state that what I picked differed in many cases from what I wanted. I love me some LotR, but the editing didn't deserve credit. Sadly, no award for "Kiss at the End of the Rainbow," but at least it wins for best Oscar performance in the hearts of viewers that are not undead. I was blue along with Murray. Penn was good; this was Murray's career best. Anyway. Good show! I'd like to thank the academy for being predictable, and also my father, without whom I'd only have been commentating to my television screen.

ganked from ** If you've had LJ for over a year, look back to one year ago today and link back to and quote from your entries of that day. If you have more than one year, go back for the same day for each past year and quote for them as well. If you've had LJ for under a year, quote from the first month you had LJ and then halfway through the time you've had it. ** On February 26th, 2003, I was at the sweeter part of the S. S. Temporary Insanity. Let's circumvent the sourer part momentarily, and glory in the joys of femininity. How lovely to rediscover one's flounce! In the grand lesson of this post, let us learn to not yammer on about our dating possibilities--though in TV terms we might liken one to Carrie's gentleman and the other to Charlotte's--until we know, for sure, that they aren't gay and taking advantage of us. I find it at least a little bit ironic that the title of that entry is "I enjoy being a girl," while I can be directly quoted as saying the following last night: "I hate being a girl! Why do girls have to over-interpret everything?!" Nevertheless, reading this entry helped me to shift focus from said interpretation, re-directing it towards the possible glories of the early moments of boy-meets-girl.

(but would someday like) This vintage deco Spa Citron ad reproduction. Any label from a lemon crate. The new DVD release of Alice In Wonderland. An adorable book called Bitter With Baggage Seeks Same, about the adventures of some chicks. Small, fluffy, toy chicks. Both soundtrack and tome for "Wicked." and

It's nice to be agreeable sometimes. Yes, I'm angry at the possibility of a constitutional amendment defining marriage. Yes, people in Los Angeles are ridiculously stupid while driving in the rain. Yes, I'm concerned about Gibson's father's antisemitism and the potential for anti-semitism stemming from the film (but I'm going to see it to judge for myself before I jump to conclusions.) Yes, that whole episode killed me, and Joss Whedon is a big mean jerk. At least he gave us some great comic relief during the evillll that was last night's episode. "I thought you'd forgotten." Classic. And, also, Good luck with that, pal.

A Potter temperament quiz behind the cut... and it's the same result from a Keirsey-style test that I've received four timees since 1991. As the book says,
Harry Potter Personality Quiz by Pirate Monkeys Inc. I like that Fred and George are ENFPs too.

Even if you're not typically a fan of theatrical lighting technology, you should check out this site because it shows some ridiculously cool architecture-lighting. Follow their "references" link to events and look at "opening of a bridge." There are several examples of the lighting (including ivy-covered and retro) and if you scroll down they also display a picture of the building unlit. It's amazing. I came across this company because, oddly enough, they've been contracted by Disneyland to light the castle to celebrate the 50th anniversary next year. Behind the cut are two such attempts. A golden anniversary theme A patriotic theme

Thanks to Mike for the questions... 1) If you were picked to, say, get all expenses paid to live anywhere in the world for six months (but only one place), where would you want to go? Well, for much of my life I would have said Los Angeles. That's moot now. I will say, without much hesitation, London. Though, actually, if I had an evening's allowance, I'd say Boston, to wave at Mike and have dinner with B before they both move to LA. (And, really, to do some area-scoping for ) 2) You and Harry Potter: What's up with that? How Simpson 134th Episode Spectacular: "What's the deal with Potter? You know what I mean." Harry Potter is a teenage wizard, he likes quiddich and chocolate frogs. Seriously, though. Between my love of children's lit, my nature as an anglophile, and my obsessive-compulsive tendencies, Potter and I are a match made in heaven. Or, if not that, some sort of limbo stasis. 3) What is your all-time favorite movie, and why? That is a difficult, difficult question to answer. I could say "Citizen Kane," because I think it's the best made. Or I could say "The Usual Suspects," because I still get the same feeling at the end as I did during the first viewing. But I'll probably say "When Harry Met Sally," because it's the one I watch every six months. It never ceases to make me laugh. 4) Fruits come in many different sizes and flavors. What fruit could you deal without ever having to see again in your lifetime? Guava, because it taunts me with its pretty. It says, mockingly, "your bowel doesn't appreciate me." And then it laughs like Nelson Muntz. 5) Okay, I was reaching a bit with that last question. Who are some of your heroes/role models in life? Well, first and foremost, my parents. I've never known anyone so kind and generous, so willing to sacrifice for their loved ones, so quick with a joke when the world seems crappy. And their marriage should be a self-help book. Professionally, Maya Derren for blazing the way for women in filmmaking and never selling out her art (though I plan to.) Spiritually, my friend, Father Truc Nguyen, who made it through the Vietnam war, a rough immigration, a thousand heartbreaks, and a career in electrical engineering and still has the compassion to reach out to his community in every way he can. The Rules: 1 - Leave a comment, saying you want to be interviewed. 2 - I will respond; I'll ask you five questions. 3 - You'll update your journal with my five questions, and your five answers. 4 - You'll include this explanation. 5 - You'll ask other people five questions when they want to be interviewed. Randomize me! This is actually a fair depiction of my taste. 1) "Making Christmas" Nightmare Before Christmas/Haunted Mansion Holiday soundtrack 2) "Trigger Happy Jack," Poe 3) "Say Yes," Elliott Smith 4) "You Belong to Me," Shrek soundtrack 5) "Beautiful World," Coldplay 6) "Across the Universe," Beatles 7) "Show Me Your Smile," Joe Wise 8) "Baby's On Fire," Velvet Goldmine soundtrack 9) "Build Me Up Buttercup," Foundations 10) "It's Summertime," Flaming Lips

Best.  Episode.  Ever.

OK, more than three words.  Who has a spare copy of the tape that you could send to Audra and I?  I beg of you.  We didn't think of taping it and it was a mistake.  Will work for puppet cancer.

This week Comcast has announced that it intends to generate a hostile takeover of Disney. Perhaps this came from left field for those of you who haven't obsessively followed the Mouse's business developments. Since my Eisner &Co gossip obsession rivals the media's Bennifer blitz (mostly because I would love to someday be on the staff of a Disney I respect-- which I do not, presently), I thought I ought to post a history of Disney kerfuffling and weigh in on the matter. It's fascinating stuff. 1966- Walt Disney dies. The company, in the hands of his brother Roy O., continues to develop his Florida project, which ends up being more of Disneyland copy than the community Walt had in mind. The Jungle Book is released; it is the last movie Walt had a hand in developing. 1971- Roy Disney dies, leaving the company to fend without its originators. Movies (not to offend the Disneyana fans, myself included) take a dive in quality. Robin Hood even copies animation movement cell-for-cell from Snow White, Jungle Book, and Aristocats. Technological animation innovation-- which Walt so championed-- is at a standstill. 1984- For all of the time and money put into the development, The Black Cauldron is a financial and critical flop. Later, the company pales next to the work of former-Dis-animator-turned-entrepreneur Don Bluth and his American Tail. It is the last straw. Things look bad for the Mouse. 1984- Roy E. Disney (Roy O's son) publicly leaves the Disney Board of Directors; makes a big fuss about how the company has turned away from its roots. 1984- Saul Steinberg plans to buy Disney by hostile takeover. In an effort to prevent this, Disney acquires more property to increase DIS stock prices-- a "poison pill." 1984- White knight Bass brothers buy up the Disney stock to prevent the possible dissolution of the company. They sell it back to Disney, but in the process return Roy Jr. back to the board and grant him chairmanship of animation. They bring in fresh blood, Eisner as CEO and Frank Wells as CFO. The "Disney Decade" is christened. 1985 to 1994- And rightfully so. Under Wells' and Eisner's guidance, the company blossoms. Roy once again champions animation technology and it begins to manifest in The Great Mouse Detective. A chain of movies follows and each tops the next in quality and box office returns. The Little Mermaid, Beauty and the Beast, Aladdin, and The Lion King prove that Disney has hit its second golden age. New theme parks pop up. The Disney Channel is premium. The Disney Store opens in a few select cities and a gigantic success. Touchstone pictures explodes into being with Who Framed Roger Rabbit. Disney acquires ABC and brings back Disney programming on Sunday nights. Disney parents Miramax, which tops the Oscars year after year. Starting with Toy Story, Disney distributes Pixar's films, and every one is a success. 1994- Frank Wells dies in a helicopter accident. The Return of Jafar, the first direct-to-video sequel, is released, thus issuing in the Disney Oversaturation Decade. Less with the focus on long-term branding and creative quality, more with the focus on the short-term Benjamins. More theme parks open; EuroDisney is a ridiculous flop until it is re-envisioned by Stephan Burke, who soon thereafter departs for Comcast. More Disney stores pop up with less interesting merchandise. Disney allows licensing through Sears, Wal-Mart, and half a billion other stores. More than one Disney movie is released per year and they're not as sharp as they used to be-- or as popular. When ABC discovers the popularity of "Who Wants to be a Millionaire," they put it on every single night. Late 90s- Paul Pressler of the Disney Store chain takes the reigns over theme parks and brings along Cynthia Harris and former military man T. Irby. None have theme park experience. They de-prioritize rides and emphasize retail. Attractions and maintenance budgets are chopped, leaving some things dirty and some things unsafe. Eisner is overheard calling park cast members "overpaid carnies." Online communities buzz with indignation. 2000- Disney's California Adventure opens. As described by Roy recently, it is built "on the cheap." The back of the park features rides straight off the midway catalogue, supposed themed as a boardwalk. Superstar Limo closes within a year thanks to the ridiculously low quality and the amount of guest complaints. A huge amount of daily gate comes from annual passholders. Online communities buzz with indignation. 2001- Eisner's bonus is reportedly out of whack with what the company earned. Business analysts begin to question his worth. Summer 2002- Lilo and Stitch is released. The second product of the Feature Animation Florida team, it is received well but not on a Lion King scale. Buzz begins about the closing of the Florida team. Online communities buzz with indignation. Winter 2002- For all of the time and money put into the development, the Feature Animation Burbank's Treasure Planet is a financial and critical flop. Later, the company pales next to the work of former-Dis-animator-turned-entrepreneur John Lasseter and his Finding Nemo. It's the last straw. Things look bad for the Mouse. Online communities buzz with indignation. Summer 2003- Ride malfunction ends in the death of a Big Thunder rider at Disneyland. The press talks about how the chopped maintenance budget is related. Winter 2003- Feature animation Florida (the financially successful team, not the less-successful Burbank) is closed. They claim that they want to centralize the process, even though much of the team is laid off. All traditionally-animated features after Home on the Range are canceled. Disney boasts that all further animated projects will be CGI, despite the fact that their only CGI film (and Dinosaur was partially CGI, at that) was a major flop, and their partnership with separate studio Pixar is on publicly shaky ground. Online communities buzz with indignation. December 2003- A new Board rule is put in place, setting an age limit for its members. Before it takes effect for him, Roy E. publicly leaves the Disney Board of Directors; makes a big fuss about how the company has turned away from its roots. Roy creates savedisney.com and begins to buzz with indignation. January 2004- Negotiations between Pixar and Disney halt. It is, supposedly, abrupt. February 2004- Comcast announces its plans to buy Disney by hostile takeover. Other companies, including Time Warner, are reportedly also considering a purchase. What now? Is it possible that, as last time, Roy Disney is in league with other entities to oust and replace the management? Will Disney swallow another poison pill? Will others swoop in to salvage or The rumor mill is working overtime. If Comcast is to take over, there is a possibility that it wouldn't be terrible. They are saying the same sorts of things that Roy says about the declining quality of the company. If they slot in Stephan Burke, he might take the care with the company that it needs if it is to return to salad days. On the flip side, they are strictly a distribution company, and their interest is probably chiefly in Disney's cable attributes-- the Disney channel, ABC Family, and undoubtedly ESPN. There is a definite possibility that this acquisition will destroy whatever "magic" the company has left. If a company like Warner snatches Disney, the outcome is similarly uncertain. Will they merge properties together and destroy the brand continuity? Will they allow Disney to function on its own? And who will chair? Great potential and great potential for floundering exists in this scenario. Personally, I'd prefer this all to happen like last time. I'd rather another investor save damsel Disney-in-distress, oust the obviously past-his-prime Eisner and replace him with a stronger option. Maybe Steve Jobs-- though I doubt he would depart from Apple (unless, say, there were an Apple-Disney merger.) Maybe Stephan Burke, without the Comcast corp. Maybe someone else. Anyway, I suspect it's a giant mud-wrestle in Burbank, and I am anxious to see in which direction this will goes. I am hoping for a change for the better. After all, the five-year-old in my heart has been personally invested in Disney for twenty years.
Ken and Barbie are calling it quits! And in the spirit of that news, an anti-valentine site for your comic hurling of words.

[whinge] I have strep throat. I hurt. I can't swallow very well. Medicine, even generic, is expensive. Perhaps I should have lived fast and died young a la James Dean so as to avoid both the price of covering my own medical expenses as well as the single-girl-must-nurse-herself-when-sick phenomenon. I can't take a sick day. I lose a week of vacation next year if I take a single one without 48 hours of warning. I can't lose a week of vacation next year. It's already slated for The Witching Hour. I have plans this weekend. I can't rest, stupid doctor. [/whinge]
my obsession with "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind":

Quoting Jennifer Aniston in regards to her home, "it's all marble and stone and hard edges and metal and nickel. It's not very kid-friendly. We've had babies of friends over to test it, and the tough ones survive banging their heads on the stone floors. It's a sexy house." A sexy baby-killing house?

she has bravado
makes jokes and bats her lashes
nothing breaks her cool

except for three words
as he leaned over her desk:
"dinner tonight, yes?"
